clinical_study.brief_title: Partnering With Media and Vaccination Program to Improve Infant and Young Child Feeding
clinical_study.official_title: Partnering With Media and Vaccination Program to Improve Infant and Young Child Feeding

collaborator.agency: Mexican National Institute of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: Infant and young child feeding (IYCF) is a key determinant of under-nutrition and overweight in young children. In Mexico, breastfeeding extends well into the second half of infancy, but animal-source foods, cereals, and legumes are not regularly provided to the child by 9 mo. This study evaluates whether knowledge and practices about dietary diversity and food consistency can be improved using a two-component intervention strategy in semi-urban communities in Mexico. The two components will deliver appropriate complementary feeding messages using: (a) nurses during the 1st National Vaccination Week (NVW); and (b) radio messages and interviews. The intervention is evaluated using a cluster randomized design in small semi-urban communities in two states in Mexico with pre- and post-test questionnaires designed to assess changes in feeding behaviors.

primary_outcome.measure: Provision of flesh-food or vitamin A-rich food
primary_outcome.description: Mothers provide at least one flesh-food (i.e., beef, chicken, fish, liver) or one vitamin A-rich fruit or vegetable in the previous day

secondary_outcome.measure: Provision of solid, semi-solid, or soft foods (i.e., not runny soups or broths) Provision of solid, semi-solid, or soft foods
secondary_outcome.description: Mothers provide solid, semi-solid, or soft foods (i.e., not runny soups or broths) at least 1 meal/d (6-12 mo) or 2 meals/d (12-24 mo)

arm_group.description: Appropriate complementary feeding messages delivered using: (a) nurses during the 1st National Vaccination Week (NVW); and (b) radio.

intervention.description: Messages delivered through National Vaccine Program and radio
